# Barbara McClintock

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

Signature  
[![Barbara McClintock

**Barbara McClintock** (June 16, 1902 – September 2, 1992) was an American
scientist and [cytogeneticist](/wiki/Cytogenetics "Cytogenetics") who was
awarded the 1983 [Nobel Prize in Physiology or
Medicine](/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physiology_or_Medicine "Nobel Prize in
Physiology or Medicine"). McClintock received her
[PhD](/wiki/Doctor_of_Philosophy "Doctor of Philosophy") in
[botany](/wiki/Botany "Botany") from [Cornell
University](/wiki/Cornell_University "Cornell University") in 1927. There she
started her career as the leader in the development of [maize](/wiki/Maize
"Maize") [cytogenetics](/wiki/Cytogenetic "Cytogenetic"), the focus of her
research for the rest of her life. From the late 1920s, McClintock studied
[chromosomes](/wiki/Chromosome "Chromosome") and how they change during
reproduction in maize. She developed the technique for visualizing [maize
chromosomes](/wiki/Maize_\(disambiguation\) "Maize \(disambiguation\)") and
used microscopic analysis to demonstrate many fundamental genetic ideas. One
of those ideas was the notion of [genetic
recombination](/wiki/Genetic_recombination "Genetic recombination") by
[crossing-over](/wiki/Chromosomal_crossover "Chromosomal crossover") during
[meiosis](/wiki/Meiosis "Meiosis")—a mechanism by which chromosomes exchange
information. She produced the first [genetic map](/wiki/Genetic_linkage
"Genetic linkage") for maize, linking regions of the chromosome to physical
traits. She demonstrated the role of the [telomere](/wiki/Telomere "Telomere")
and [centromere](/wiki/Centromere "Centromere"), regions of the chromosome
that are important in the conservation of [genetic
information](/wiki/Genetic_information "Genetic information"). She was
recognized among the best in the field, awarded prestigious fellowships, and
elected a member of the [National Academy of
Sciences](/wiki/United_States_National_Academy_of_Sciences "United States
National Academy of Sciences") in 1944.

During the 1940s and 1950s, McClintock discovered
[transposition](/wiki/Transposon "Transposon") and used it to demonstrate that
[genes](/wiki/Gene "Gene") are responsible for turning physical
characteristics on and off. She developed theories to explain the suppression
and expression of genetic information from one generation of maize plants to
the next. Due to skepticism of her research and its implications, she stopped
publishing her data in 1953.

Later, she made an extensive study of the cytogenetics and
[ethnobotany](/wiki/Ethnobotany "Ethnobotany") of maize
[races](/wiki/Race_\(biology\) "Race \(biology\)") from South America.
McClintock's research became well understood in the 1960s and 1970s, as other
scientists confirmed the mechanisms of genetic change and [genetic
regulation](/wiki/Regulation_of_gene_expression "Regulation of gene
expression") that she had demonstrated in her maize research in the 1940s and
1950s. Awards and recognition for her contributions to the field followed,
including the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, awarded to her in 1983
for the discovery of genetic [transposition](/wiki/Transposon "Transposon");
she is the only woman to receive an unshared [Nobel Prize](/wiki/Nobel_Prize
"Nobel Prize") in that category.[1]

## Early
life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Barbara_McClintock&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Early life")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/McClintock_family_1907.jpg/300px-
McClintock_family_1907.jpg)](/wiki/File:McClintock_family_1907.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:McClintock_family_1907.jpg "Enlarge")

McClintock children, from left to right: Mignon, Malcolm Rider "Tom", Barbara
and Marjorie

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/McClintock_family.jpg/300px-
McClintock_family.jpg)](/wiki/File:McClintock_family.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:McClintock_family.jpg "Enlarge")

McClintock family, from left to right: Mignon, Tom, Barbara, Marjorie and Sara
(at the piano)

Barbara McClintock was born Eleanor McClintock on June 16, 1902 in
[Hartford](/wiki/Hartford,_Connecticut "Hartford, Connecticut"),
[Connecticut](/wiki/Connecticut "Connecticut"),[2][3] the third of four
children born to physician Thomas Henry McClintock and Sara Handy McClintock.
Thomas McClintock was the child of British immigrants, and Sara Ryder Handy,
descended from an old American _[Mayflower](/wiki/Mayflower "Mayflower")_
family.[3][4] Marjorie, the oldest child, was born in October 1898; Mignon,
the second daughter, was born in November 1900. The youngest, Malcolm Rider
(called Tom), was born 18 months after Barbara. As a young girl, her parents
determined that [Eleanor](/wiki/Eleanor "Eleanor"), a "feminine" and
"delicate" name, was not appropriate for her, and chose
[Barbara](/wiki/Barbara_\(given_name\) "Barbara \(given name\)")
instead.[3][4] McClintock was an independent child beginning at a very young
age, a trait she later identified as her "capacity to be alone". From the age
of three until she began school, McClintock lived with an aunt and uncle in
Brooklyn, New York in order to reduce the financial burden on her parents
while her father established his medical practice. She was described as a
solitary and independent child. She was close to her father, but had a
difficult relationship with her mother, tension that began when she was
young.[3][4]

The McClintock family moved to Brooklyn in 1908 and McClintock completed her
secondary education there at [Erasmus Hall High
School](/wiki/Erasmus_Hall_High_School "Erasmus Hall High School");[4][5] she
graduated early in 1919.[2] She discovered her love of science and reaffirmed
her solitary personality during high school.[3] She wanted to continue her
studies at [Cornell University](/wiki/Cornell_University "Cornell
University")'s College of Agriculture. Her mother resisted sending McClintock
to college, for fear that she would be unmarriageable.[4] McClintock was
almost prevented from starting college, but her father intervened just before
registration began, and she matriculated at Cornell in 1919.[6][7]

## Education and research at
Cornell[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Barbara_McClintock&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Education and research at Cornell")]

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Audio-input-microphone.svg/50px-Audio-input-microphone.svg.png) |  [Barbara McClintock (As Told By Jo Handelsman)](/wiki/File:Barbara_McClintock_\(As_Told_By_Jo_Handelsman\).ogg "File:Barbara McClintock \(As Told By Jo Handelsman\).ogg") ![](data:image/png,%89PNG%0D%0A%1A%0A%00%00%00%0DIHDR%00%00%00%01%00%00%00%01%08%02%00%00%00%90wS%DE%00%00%00%01sRGB%00%AE%CE%1C%E9%00%00%00%09pHYs%00%00%0B%13%00%00%0B%13%01%00%9A%9C%18%00%00%00%07tIME%07%DB%0B%0A%17%041%80%9B%E7%F2%00%00%00%19tEXtComment%00Created%20with%20GIMPW%81%0E%17%00%00%00%0CIDAT%08%D7c%60%60%60%00%00%00%04%00%01'4'%0A%00%00%00%00IEND%AEB%60%82)[](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/d/dc/Barbara_McClintock_%28As_Told_By_Jo_Handelsman%29.ogg/Barbara_McClintock_%28As_Told_By_Jo_Handelsman%29.ogg.mp3)

McClintock began her studies at Cornell's [College of
Agriculture](/wiki/Cornell_University_College_of_Agriculture_and_Life_Sciences
"Cornell University College of Agriculture and Life Sciences") in 1919. There,
she participated in [student government](/wiki/Student_government "Student
government") and was invited to join a [sorority](/wiki/Sorority "Sorority"),
though she soon realized that she preferred not to join formal organizations.
Instead, McClintock took up music, specifically [jazz](/wiki/Jazz "Jazz"). She
studied [botany](/wiki/Botany "Botany"), receiving a
[BSc](/wiki/Bachelor_of_Science "Bachelor of Science") in 1923.[6] Her
interest in genetics began when she took her first course in that field in
1921. The course was based on a similar one offered at Harvard University, and
was taught by [C. B. Hutchison](/wiki/C._B._Hutchison "C. B. Hutchison"), a
plant breeder and geneticist.[8][9][10] Hutchison was impressed by
McClintock's interest, and telephoned to invite her to participate in the
graduate genetics course at Cornell in 1922. McClintock pointed to Hutchison's
invitation as the reason she continued in genetics: "Obviously, this telephone
call cast the die for my future. I remained with genetics thereafter."[11]
Although it has been reported that women could not major in genetics at
Cornell, and therefore her MS and PhD—earned in 1925 and 1927,
respectively—were officially awarded in botany, recent research has revealed
that women did earn graduate degrees in Cornell's Plant Breeding Department
during the time that McClintock was a student at Cornell.[12]

During her graduate studies and postgraduate appointment as a botany
instructor, McClintock was instrumental in assembling a group that studied the
new field of [cytogenetics](/wiki/Cytogenetics "Cytogenetics") in
[maize](/wiki/Maize "Maize"). This group brought together plant breeders and
cytologists, and included [Marcus Rhoades](/wiki/Marcus_Rhoades "Marcus
Rhoades"), future [Nobel](/wiki/Nobel_Prize "Nobel Prize") laureate [George
Beadle](/wiki/George_Beadle "George Beadle"), and [Harriet
Creighton](/wiki/Harriet_Creighton "Harriet Creighton").[13][14][15] [Rollins
A. Emerson](/wiki/Rollins_A._Emerson "Rollins A. Emerson"), head of the Plant
Breeding Department, supported these efforts, although he was not a cytologist
himself.[16][17]

She also worked as a research assistant for [Lowell Fitz
Randolph](/wiki/Lowell_Fitz_Randolph "Lowell Fitz Randolph") and then for
[Lester W. Sharp](/wiki/Lester_W._Sharp "Lester W. Sharp"), both Cornell
Botanists.[18]

McClintock's cytogenetic research focused on developing ways to visualize and
characterize maize chromosomes. This particular part of her work influenced a
generation of students, as it was included in most textbooks. She also
developed a technique using [carmine](/wiki/Carmine "Carmine") staining to
visualize maize chromosomes, and showed for the first time the morphology of
the 10 maize chromosomes. This discovery was made because she observed cells
from the [microspore](/wiki/Microspore "Microspore") as opposed to the [root
tip](/wiki/Root_cap "Root cap").[16][19] By studying the morphology of the
chromosomes, McClintock was able to [link](/wiki/Genetic_linkage "Genetic
linkage") specific chromosome groups of traits that were inherited
together.[20] Marcus Rhoades noted that McClintock's 1929
_[Genetics](/wiki/Genetics_\(journal\) "Genetics \(journal\)")_ paper on the
characterization of [triploid](/wiki/Polyploidy "Polyploidy") maize
chromosomes triggered scientific interest in maize cytogenetics, and
attributed to her 10 of the 17 significant advances in the field that were
made by Cornell scientists between 1929 and 1935.[21]

In 1930, McClintock was the first person to describe the cross-shaped
interaction of homologous chromosomes during [meiosis](/wiki/Meiosis
"Meiosis"). The following year, McClintock and Creighton proved the link
between [chromosomal crossover](/wiki/Chromosomal_crossover "Chromosomal
crossover") during meiosis and the recombination of genetic traits.[20][22]
They observed how the recombination of chromosomes seen under a microscope
correlated with new traits.[15][23] Until this point, it had only been
hypothesized that [genetic recombination](/wiki/Genetic_recombination "Genetic
recombination") could occur during meiosis, although it had not been shown
genetically.[15] McClintock published the first genetic map for maize in 1931,
showing the order of three genes on maize chromosome 9.[24] This information
provided necessary data for the crossing-over study she published with
Creighton;[22] they also showed that crossing-over occurs in [sister
chromatids](/wiki/Sister_chromatids "Sister chromatids") as well as
[homologous chromosomes](/wiki/Homologous_chromosomes "Homologous
chromosomes").[25] In 1938, she produced a cytogenetic analysis of the
[centromere](/wiki/Centromere "Centromere"), describing the organization and
function of the centromere, as well as the fact that it can divide.[20]

McClintock's breakthrough publications, and support from her colleagues, led
to her being awarded several postdoctoral fellowships from the [National
Research Council](/wiki/United_States_National_Research_Council "United States
National Research Council"). This funding allowed her to continue to study
genetics at Cornell, the [University of Missouri](/wiki/University_of_Missouri
"University of Missouri"), and the [California Institute of
Technology](/wiki/California_Institute_of_Technology "California Institute of
Technology"), where she worked with E. G. Anderson.[12][25] During the summers
of 1931 and 1932, she worked at Missouri with geneticist [Lewis
Stadler](/wiki/Lewis_Stadler "Lewis Stadler"), who introduced her to the use
of [X-rays](/wiki/X-ray "X-ray") as a [mutagen](/wiki/Mutagen "Mutagen").
Exposure to X-rays can increase the rate of mutation above the natural
background level, making it a powerful research tool for genetics. Through her
work with X-ray-mutagenized maize, she identified [ring
chromosomes](/wiki/Ring_chromosome "Ring chromosome"), which form when the
ends of a single chromosome fuse together after radiation damage.[26] From
this evidence, McClintock hypothesized that there must be a structure on the
chromosome tip that would normally ensure stability. She showed that the loss
of ring-chromosomes at meiosis caused [variegation](/wiki/Variegation
"Variegation") in maize foliage in generations subsequent to irradiation
resulting from chromosomal deletion.[20] During this period, she demonstrated
the presence of the [nucleolus organizer
region](/wiki/Nucleolus_organizer_region "Nucleolus organizer region") on a
region on maize chromosome 6, which is required for the assembly of the
[nucleolus](/wiki/Nucleolus "Nucleolus").[20][25][27] In 1933, she established
that cells can be damaged when [nonhomologous recombination](/wiki/Non-
homologous_end_joining "Non-homologous end joining") occurs.[20][28] During
this same period, McClintock hypothesized that the tips of chromosomes are
protected by [telomeres](/wiki/Telomere "Telomere").[29]

McClintock received a fellowship from the [Guggenheim
Foundation](/wiki/John_Simon_Guggenheim_Memorial_Foundation "John Simon
Guggenheim Memorial Foundation") that made possible six months of training in
Germany during 1933 and 1934.[26] She had planned to work with [Curt
Stern](/wiki/Curt_Stern_\(geneticist\) "Curt Stern \(geneticist\)"), who had
demonstrated crossing-over in _[Drosophila](/wiki/Drosophila "Drosophila")_
just weeks after McClintock and Creighton had done so; however, Stern
emigrated to the United States. Instead, she worked with geneticist [Richard
B. Goldschmidt](/wiki/Richard_B._Goldschmidt "Richard B. Goldschmidt"), who
was the head of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute.[4] She left Germany early amidst
mounting political tension in Europe, and returned to Cornell, remaining there
until 1936, when she accepted an Assistant Professorship offered to her by
Lewis Stadler in the Department of Botany at the University of Missouri-
Columbia.[30][31] While still at Cornell, she was supported by a two-year
[Rockefeller Foundation](/wiki/Rockefeller_Foundation "Rockefeller
Foundation") grant obtained for her through Emerson's efforts.[26]

## University of
Missouri[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Barbara_McClintock&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: University of Missouri")]

During her time at Missouri, McClintock expanded her research on the effect of
X-rays on maize cytogenetics. McClintock observed the breakage and fusion of
chromosomes in irradiated maize cells. She was also able to show that, in some
plants, spontaneous chromosome breakage occurred in the cells of the
endosperm. Over the course of [mitosis](/wiki/Mitosis "Mitosis"), she observed
that the ends of broken chromatids were rejoined after the chromosome
[replication](/wiki/DNA_replication "DNA replication").[32] In the
[anaphase](/wiki/Anaphase "Anaphase") of mitosis, the broken chromosomes
formed a chromatid bridge, which was broken when the chromatids moved towards
the cell poles. The broken ends were rejoined in the
[interphase](/wiki/Interphase "Interphase") of the next mitosis, and the cycle
was repeated, causing massive mutation, which she could detect as variegation
in the endosperm.[33] This [breakage–rejoining–bridge cycle](/wiki/Breakage-
fusion-bridge_cycle "Breakage-fusion-bridge cycle") was a key cytogenetic
discovery for several reasons.[32] First, it showed that the rejoining of
chromosomes was not a random event, and second, it demonstrated a source of
large-scale mutation. For this reason, it remains an area of interest in
[cancer](/wiki/Cancer "Cancer") research today.[34]

Although her research was progressing at Missouri, McClintock was not
satisfied with her position at the University. She recalled being excluded
from faculty meetings, and was not made aware of positions available at other
institutions.[4] In 1940, she wrote to Charles Burnham, "I have decided that I
must look for another job. As far as I can make out, there is nothing more for
me here. I am an assistant professor at $3,000 and I feel sure that that is
the limit for me."[35][32] Initially, McClintock's position was created
especially for her by Stadler, and might have depended on his presence at the
university.[12][30] McClintock believed she would not gain
[tenure](/wiki/Tenure "Tenure") at Missouri, even though according to some
accounts, she knew she would be offered a promotion from Missouri in the
spring of 1942.[36] Recent evidence reveals that McClintock more likely
decided to leave Missouri because she had lost trust in her employer and in
the University administration, after discovering that her job would be in
jeopardy if Stadler were to leave for [Caltech](/wiki/Caltech "Caltech"), as
he had considered doing. The university's retaliation against Stadler
amplified her sentiments.[12]

In early 1941, she took a leave of absence from Missouri in hopes of finding a
position elsewhere. She accepted a visiting Professorship at [Columbia
University](/wiki/Columbia_University "Columbia University"), where her former
Cornell colleague [Marcus Rhoades](/wiki/Marcus_Rhoades "Marcus Rhoades") was
a professor. Rhoades also offered to share his research field at Cold Spring
Harbor on Long Island. In December 1941, she was offered a research position
by [Milislav Demerec](/wiki/Milislav_Demerec "Milislav Demerec"), the newly
appointed acting director of the [Carnegie Institution of
Washington](/wiki/Carnegie_Institution_of_Washington "Carnegie Institution of
Washington")'s Department of Genetics [Cold Spring Harbor
Laboratory](/wiki/Cold_Spring_Harbor_Laboratory "Cold Spring Harbor
Laboratory"); McClintock accepted his invitation despite her qualms and became
a permanent member of the faculty.[37]

## Cold Spring
Harbor[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Barbara_McClintock&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Cold Spring Harbor")]

After her year-long temporary appointment, McClintock accepted a full-time
research position at [Cold Spring Harbor
Laboratory](/wiki/Cold_Spring_Harbor_Laboratory "Cold Spring Harbor
Laboratory"). There, she was highly productive and continued her work with the
breakage-fusion-bridge cycle, using it to substitute for X-rays as a tool for
mapping new genes. In 1944, in recognition of her prominence in the field of
genetics during this period, McClintock was elected to the [National Academy
of Sciences](/wiki/United_States_National_Academy_of_Sciences "United States
National Academy of Sciences")—only the third woman to be elected. That same
year, she became the first female president of the [Genetics Society of
America](/wiki/Genetics_Society_of_America "Genetics Society of America");[2]
she was elected its vice-president in 1939.[31] In 1944 she undertook a
cytogenetic analysis of _[Neurospora crassa](/wiki/Neurospora_crassa
"Neurospora crassa")_ at the suggestion of George Beadle, who used the fungus
to demonstrate the one gene–one enzyme relationship. He invited her to
[Stanford](/wiki/Stanford_University "Stanford University") to undertake the
study. She successfully described the number of chromosomes, or
[karyotype](/wiki/Karyotype "Karyotype"), of _N. crassa_ and described the
entire life cycle of the species. Beadle said "Barbara, in two months at
Stanford, did more to clean up the cytology of Neurospora than all other
cytological geneticists had done in all previous time on all forms of mold."
[38] _N. crassa_ has since become a [model species](/wiki/Model_organism
"Model organism") for classical genetic analysis.[39][40]

### Discovery of controlling
elements[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Barbara_McClintock&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Discovery of controlling elements")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Corn_mosaic.jpg/220px-
Corn_mosaic.jpg)](/wiki/File:Corn_mosaic.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Corn_mosaic.jpg "Enlarge")

The relationship of _Ac/Ds_ in the control of the elements and mosaic color of
maize. The seed in 10 is colorless, there is no _Ac_ element present and _Ds_
inhibits the synthesis of colored pigments called
[anthocyanins](/wiki/Anthocyanin "Anthocyanin"). In 11 to 13, one copy of _Ac_
is present. _Ds_ can move and some anthocyanin is produced, creating a mosaic
pattern. In the kernel in panel 14 there are two _Ac_ elements and in 15 there
are three.

In the summer of 1944 at [Cold Spring Harbor
Laboratory](/wiki/Cold_Spring_Harbor_Laboratory "Cold Spring Harbor
Laboratory"), McClintock began systematic studies on the mechanisms of the
[mosaic](/wiki/Mosaic_\(genetics\) "Mosaic \(genetics\)") color patterns of
maize seed and the unstable [inheritance](/wiki/Biological_inheritance
"Biological inheritance") of this mosaicism.[41] She identified two new
[dominant](/wiki/Dominance_relationship "Dominance relationship") and
interacting genetic loci that she named _Dissociator_ (_Ds_) and _Activator_
(_Ac_). She found that the _Dissociator_ did not just dissociate or cause the
chromosome to break, it also had a variety of effects on neighboring genes
when the _Activator_ was also present, which included making certain stable
mutations unstable. In early 1948, she made the surprising discovery that both
_Dissociator_ and _Activator_ could transpose, or change position, on the
chromosome.[42][43][44][45]

She observed the effects of the transposition of _Ac_ and _Ds_ by the changing
patterns of coloration in maize kernels over generations of controlled
crosses, and described the relationship between the two
[loci](/wiki/Locus_\(genetics\) "Locus \(genetics\)") through intricate
microscopic analysis.[46][47] She concluded that _Ac_ controls the
transposition of the _Ds_ from chromosome 9, and that the movement of _Ds_ is
accompanied by the breakage of the chromosome.[45] When _Ds_ moves, the
[aleurone](/wiki/Aleurone "Aleurone")-color gene is released from the
suppressing effect of the _Ds_ and transformed into the active form, which
initiates the pigment synthesis in cells.[48] The transposition of _Ds_ in
different cells is random, it may move in some but not others, which causes
color mosaicism. The size of the colored spot on the seed is determined by
stage of the seed development during dissociation. McClintock also found that
the transposition of _Ds_ is determined by the number of _Ac_ copies in the
cell.[49]

Between 1948 and 1950, she developed a theory by which these mobile elements
regulated the genes by inhibiting or modulating their action. She referred to
_Dissociator_ and _Activator_ as "controlling units"—later, as "controlling
elements"—to distinguish them from genes. She hypothesized that [gene
regulation](/wiki/Gene_regulation "Gene regulation") could explain how complex
multicellular organisms made of cells with identical [genomes](/wiki/Genome
"Genome") have cells of different function.[49] McClintock's discovery
challenged the concept of the genome as a static set of instructions passed
between generations.[2] In 1950, she reported her work on _Ac/Ds_ and her
ideas about gene regulation in a paper entitled "The origin and behavior of
mutable loci in maize" published in the journal _[Proceedings of the National
Academy of Sciences](/wiki/Proceedings_of_the_National_Academy_of_Sciences
"Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences")_. In summer 1951, she
reported her work on the origin and behavior of mutable loci in maize at the
annual symposium at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, presenting a paper of the
same name. The paper delved into the instability caused by _Dc_ and _As_ or
just _As_ in four genes, along with the tendency of those genes to
unpredictably revert to the wild phenotype. She also identified "families" of
transposons, which did not interact with one another.[2][50][45]

Her work on controlling elements and gene regulation was conceptually
difficult and was not immediately understood or accepted by her
contemporaries; she described the reception of her research as "puzzlement,
even hostility".[51][45] Nevertheless, McClintock continued to develop her
ideas on controlling elements. She published a paper in
_[Genetics](/wiki/Genetics_\(journal\) "Genetics \(journal\)")_ in 1953, where
she presented all her statistical data, and undertook lecture tours to
universities throughout the 1950s to speak about her work.[52] She continued
to investigate the problem and identified a new element that she called
_Suppressor-mutator_ (_Spm_), which, although similar to _Ac/Ds_ , acts in a
more complex manner. Like _Ac/Ds_ , some versions could transpose on their own
and some could not; unlike _Ac/Ds_ , when present, it fully suppressed the
expression of mutant genes when they normally would not be entirely
suppressed.[53] Based on the reactions of other scientists to her work,
McClintock felt she risked alienating the scientific mainstream, and from 1953
stopped publishing accounts of her research on controlling elements.[2][43]

### The origins of
maize[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Barbara_McClintock&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: The origins of maize")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Corn_and_microscope.jpg/220px-
Corn_and_microscope.jpg)](/wiki/File:Corn_and_microscope.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Corn_and_microscope.jpg "Enlarge")

McClintock's microscope and ears of corn on exhibition at the [National Museum
of Natural History](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Natural_History "National Museum
of Natural History")

In 1957, McClintock received funding from the [National Academy of
Sciences](/wiki/National_Academy_of_Sciences "National Academy of Sciences")
to start research on indigenous strains of maize in [Central
America](/wiki/Central_America "Central America") and [South
America](/wiki/South_America "South America"). She was interested in studying
the [evolution](/wiki/Evolution "Evolution") of maize through chromosomal
changes,[54] and being in South America would allow her to work on a larger
scale. McClintock explored the chromosomal, morphological, and evolutionary
characteristics of various [races](/wiki/Race_\(biology\) "Race \(biology\)")
of maize.[55][29] After extensive work in the 1960s and 1970s, McClintock and
her collaborators published the seminal study _The Chromosomal Constitution of
Races of Maize_ , leaving their mark on [paleobotany](/wiki/Paleobotany
"Paleobotany"), [ethnobotany](/wiki/Ethnobotany "Ethnobotany"), and
[evolutionary biology](/wiki/Evolutionary_biology "Evolutionary biology").[56]

###
Rediscovery[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Barbara_McClintock&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Rediscovery")]

McClintock officially retired from her position at the Carnegie Institution in
1967,[2] and was made a Distinguished Service Member of the Carnegie
Institution of Washington.[37] This honor allowed her to continue working with
graduate students and colleagues in the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory as
_scientist emerita_ ; she lived in the town.[57] In reference to her decision
20 years earlier to stop publishing detailed accounts of her work on
controlling elements, she wrote in 1973:

> Over the years I have found that it is difficult if not impossible to bring
> to consciousness of another person the nature of his tacit assumptions when,
> by some special experiences, I have been made aware of them. This became
> painfully evident to me in my attempts during the 1950s to convince
> geneticists that the action of genes had to be and was controlled. It is now
> equally painful to recognize the fixity of assumptions that many persons
> hold on the nature of controlling elements in maize and the manners of their
> operation. One must await the right time for conceptual change.[58]

The importance of McClintock's contributions was revealed in the 1960s, when
the work of French geneticists [Francois Jacob](/wiki/Francois_Jacob "Francois
Jacob") and [Jacques Monod](/wiki/Jacques_Monod "Jacques Monod") described the
genetic regulation of the [_lac_ operon](/wiki/Lac_operon "Lac operon"), a
concept she had demonstrated with _Ac/Ds_ in 1951. Following Jacob and Monod's
1961 _Journal of Molecular Biology_ paper "Genetic regulatory mechanisms in
the synthesis of proteins", McClintock wrote an article for _[American
Naturalist](/wiki/American_Naturalist "American Naturalist")_ comparing the
_lac_ operon and her work on controlling elements in maize.[59][53]
McClintock's contribution to biology is still not widely acknowledged as
amounting to the discovery of genetic regulation.[43]

McClintock was widely credited with discovering transposition after other
researchers finally discovered the process in bacteria, yeast, and
[bacteriophages](/wiki/Bacteriophage "Bacteriophage") in the late 1960s and
early 1970s.[60] During this period, molecular biology had developed
significant new technology, and scientists were able to show the molecular
basis for transposition.[61] In the 1970s, _Ac_ and _Ds_ were
[cloned](/wiki/Cloning "Cloning") by other scientists and were shown to be
[Class II transposons](/wiki/Transposon "Transposon"). _Ac_ is a complete
transposon that can produce a functional [transposase](/wiki/Transposase
"Transposase"), which is required for the element to move within the genome.
_Ds_ has a mutation in its transposase gene, which means that it cannot move
without another source of transposase. Thus, as McClintock observed, _Ds_
cannot move in the absence of _Ac_. _Spm_ has also been characterized as a
transposon. Subsequent research has shown that transposons typically do not
move unless the cell is placed under stress, such as by irradiation or the
[breakage-fusion-bridge cycle](/wiki/Breakage-fusion-bridge_cycle "Breakage-
fusion-bridge cycle"), and thus their activation during stress can serve as a
source of genetic variation for evolution.[62] McClintock understood the role
of transposons in evolution and genome change well before other researchers
grasped the concept. Nowadays, _Ac/Ds_ is used as a tool in plant biology to
generate mutant plants used for the characterization of gene function.[63]

## Honors and
recognition[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Barbara_McClintock&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Honors and recognition")]

In 1947, McClintock received the Achievement Award from the [American
Association of University
Women](/wiki/American_Association_of_University_Women "American Association of
University Women"). She was elected a Fellow of the [American Academy of Arts
and Sciences](/wiki/American_Academy_of_Arts_and_Sciences "American Academy of
Arts and Sciences") in 1959.[64] In 1967, McClintock was awarded the Kimber
Genetics Award;[65] three years later, she was given the [National Medal of
Science](/wiki/National_Medal_of_Science "National Medal of Science") by
[Richard Nixon](/wiki/Richard_Nixon "Richard Nixon") in 1970.[60][66] She was
the first woman to be awarded the National Medal of Science.[67] Cold Spring
Harbor named a building in her honor in 1973.[29] She received the Louis and
Bert Freedman Foundation Award and the Lewis S. Rosensteil Award in 1978.[65]
In 1981, she became the first recipient of the [MacArthur Foundation
Grant](/wiki/MacArthur_Foundation "MacArthur Foundation"), and was awarded the
[Albert Lasker Award for Basic Medical
Research](/wiki/Albert_Lasker_Award_for_Basic_Medical_Research "Albert Lasker
Award for Basic Medical Research"),[68] the [Wolf Prize in
Medicine](/wiki/Wolf_Prize_in_Medicine "Wolf Prize in Medicine") and the
[Thomas Hunt Morgan Medal](/wiki/Thomas_Hunt_Morgan_Medal "Thomas Hunt Morgan
Medal") by the Genetics Society of America. In 1982, she was awarded the
[Louisa Gross Horwitz Prize](/wiki/Louisa_Gross_Horwitz_Prize "Louisa Gross
Horwitz Prize") from [Columbia University](/wiki/Columbia_University "Columbia
University") for her research in the "evolution of genetic information and the
control of its expression."[69][29]

Most notably, she received the [Nobel Prize for Physiology or
Medicine](/wiki/Nobel_Prize_for_Physiology_or_Medicine "Nobel Prize for
Physiology or Medicine") in 1983, the first woman to win that prize
unshared,[57] credited by the [Nobel Foundation](/wiki/Nobel_Foundation "Nobel
Foundation") for discovering "[mobile genetic elements](/wiki/Transposon
"Transposon")";[70] it was more than 30 years after she initially described
the phenomenon of controlling elements. She was compared to [Gregor
Mendel](/wiki/Gregor_Mendel "Gregor Mendel") in terms of her scientific career
by the [Swedish Academy of Sciences](/wiki/Swedish_Academy_of_Sciences
"Swedish Academy of Sciences") when she was awarded the Prize.[71]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/McClintock_Nobel_Lecture.jpg/220px-
McClintock_Nobel_Lecture.jpg)](/wiki/File:McClintock_Nobel_Lecture.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:McClintock_Nobel_Lecture.jpg "Enlarge")

McClintock giving her Nobel Lecture

She was elected a [Foreign Member of the Royal Society (ForMemRS) in
1989](/wiki/List_of_Fellows_of_the_Royal_Society_elected_in_1989 "List of
Fellows of the Royal Society elected in 1989").[72] McClintock received the
[Benjamin Franklin Medal for Distinguished Achievement in the
Sciences](/wiki/Benjamin_Franklin_Medal_for_Distinguished_Achievement_in_the_Sciences
"Benjamin Franklin Medal for Distinguished Achievement in the Sciences") of
the [American Philosophical Society](/wiki/American_Philosophical_Society
"American Philosophical Society") in 1993.[73] She was awarded 14 Honorary
Doctor of Science degrees and an Honorary Doctor of Humane Letters.[29] In
1986 she was inducted into the [National Women's Hall of
Fame](/wiki/National_Women%27s_Hall_of_Fame "National Women's Hall of Fame").
During her final years, McClintock led a more public life, especially after
[Evelyn Fox Keller](/wiki/Evelyn_Fox_Keller "Evelyn Fox Keller")'s 1983
biography of her, _A Feeling for the Organism,_ brought McClintock's story to
the public. She remained a regular presence in the Cold Spring Harbor
community, and gave talks on mobile genetic elements and the history of
genetics research for the benefit of junior scientists. An anthology of her 43
publications _The Discovery and Characterization of Transposable Elements: The
Collected Papers of Barbara McClintock_ was published in 1987.[68]

## Later
years[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Barbara_McClintock&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: Later years")]

McClintock spent her later years, post Nobel Prize, as a key leader and
researcher in the field at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory on Long Island, New
York. McClintock died of natural causes in
[Huntington](/wiki/Huntington,_New_York "Huntington, New York"), [New
York](/wiki/New_York_\(state\) "New York \(state\)"), on September 2, 1992 at
the age of 90; she never married or had children.[57][68]

## Legacy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Barbara_McClintock&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Legacy")]

Since her death, McClintock has been the subject of a biography by the science
historian [Nathaniel C. Comfort](/wiki/Nathaniel_C._Comfort "Nathaniel C.
Comfort")'s _The Tangled Field: Barbara McClintock 's Search for the Patterns
of Genetic Control_. Comfort's biography contests some claims about
McClintock, described as the "McClintock Myth", which he claims was
perpetuated by the earlier biography by Keller. Keller's thesis was that
McClintock was long ignored or met with derision because she was a woman
working in the sciences. For example, when McClintock presented her findings
that the genetics of maize did not conform to Mendelian distributions,
geneticist [Sewall Wright](/wiki/Sewall_Wright "Sewall Wright") expressed the
belief that she did not understand the underlying mathematics of her work, a
belief he had expressed towards other women at the time.[74] In addition,
geneticist Lotte Auerbach recounted that [Joshua
Lederberg](/wiki/Joshua_Lederberg "Joshua Lederberg") returned from a visit to
McClintock's lab with the remark: 'By God, that woman is either crazy or a
genius.' " As Auerbach tells it, McClintock had thrown Lederberg and his
colleagues out after half an hour 'because of their arrogance. She was
intolerant of arrogance ... She felt she had crossed a desert alone and no one
had followed her.'"[75][76]

Comfort, however, asserts that McClintock was well regarded by her
professional peers, even in the early years of her career.[77] Although
Comfort argues that McClintock was not a victim of gender discrimination, she
has been widely written about in the context of women's studies. Most recent
biographical works on women in science feature accounts of her experience. She
is held up as a role model for girls in such works of children's literature as
Edith Hope Fine's _Barbara McClintock, Nobel Prize Geneticist_ , Deborah
Heiligman's _Barbara McClintock: Alone in Her Field_ and Mary Kittredge's
_Barbara McClintock_. A recent biography for young adults by Naomi Pasachoff,
_Barbara McClintock, Genius of Genetics_ , provides a new perspective, based
on the current literature.[78]

On 4 May 2005, the [United States Postal
Service](/wiki/United_States_Postal_Service "United States Postal Service")
issued the "American Scientists" commemorative [postage
stamp](/wiki/Postage_stamp "Postage stamp") series, a set of four 37-cent
self-adhesive stamps in several configurations. The scientists depicted were
Barbara McClintock, [John von Neumann](/wiki/John_von_Neumann "John von
Neumann"), [Josiah Willard Gibbs](/wiki/Josiah_Willard_Gibbs "Josiah Willard
Gibbs"), and [Richard Feynman](/wiki/Richard_Feynman "Richard Feynman").
McClintock was also featured in a 1989 four-stamp issue from
[Sweden](/wiki/Sweden "Sweden") which illustrated the work of eight Nobel
Prize-winning geneticists. A small building at Cornell University and a
laboratory building at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory were named for her. A
street has been named after her in the new "[Adlershof Development
Society](/wiki/Adlershof#Development "Adlershof")" science park in
[Berlin](/wiki/Berlin "Berlin").[79]

Some of McClintock's personality and scientific achievements were referred to
in [Jeffrey Eugenides](/wiki/Jeffrey_Eugenides "Jeffrey Eugenides")'s 2011
novel _[The Marriage Plot](/wiki/The_Marriage_Plot "The Marriage Plot"),_
which tells the story of a [yeast](/wiki/Yeast "Yeast") geneticist named
Leonard who suffers from [bipolar disorder](/wiki/Bipolar_disorder "Bipolar
disorder"). He works at a laboratory loosely based on Cold Spring Harbor. The
character reminiscent of McClintock is a reclusive geneticist at the fictional
laboratory, who makes the same discoveries as her factual counterpart.[80]

Judith Pratt wrote a play about McClintock, called MAIZE, which was read at
Artemesia Theatre in Chicago in 2015, and will be produced in Ithaca NY--the
home of Cornell University--in February-March 2018.
